titleStmt.title: The resolution of the army, concerning the Kings Majesties going to Richmond, and their further determination touching their proceedings with the Parliament of England, and the citizens of London. Likewise his Majesties last propositions to the Honourable Houses of Parliament assembled at Westminster, and his loyall and faithfull subjects, the citizens of London. Wherein is declared, His Majesties gallant resolution to unite himselfe with his two houses of Parliament, and to settle peace and truth within the kingdome of England, and dominion of Wales. Together with certain propositions sent from His Majesties royal court at Newmarket, to his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax at St. Albanes, concerning the Kings Majesty, the Parliament, and the army.
titleStmt.author: Woorell, A.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 7 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE RESOLVTION OF THE ARMY, concerning the Kings Maje≈øties going to Richmond, and their further determination touching their proceedings with the Parliament of England, and the Citizens of London.
Likewi≈øe his Maje≈øties la≈øt PROPOSITIONS TO THE Honorable Hou≈øes of Parliament a≈ø≈øembled at We≈øtmin≈øter, and His loyall and faithfull Subjects, the Citi≈øens of London.
Wherein is declared, His Maje≈øties gallant Re≈øolution to unite Him≈øelfe with His two Hou≈øes of Parliament and to ≈øettle peace and Truth within the Kingdome of England, and Dominion of Wales.

Together with certaine Propo≈øitions ≈øent from His Maje≈øties Royal Court at Newmarket, to his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax at St. Albanes, concerning the Kings Maje≈øty, the Parliament, and the ARMY.
London Printed for Iohn Willet, Iune 24. 1647.

div.head: The Kings MAJESTIES De≈øires and Propo≈øitions To both hou≈øes of Parliament, and the Citizens of London concerning the pre≈øervation and ≈øafety of His Maje≈øties Royall Per≈øon.

div.p:
HAving received your la≈øt, dated June 19. I find an earne≈øt expre≈ø≈øion, wherin you de≈øire to be ≈øatisfied in that great bu≈øine≈ø≈øe now in di≈øpenbe betwixt the King, Parliament, and Army; and indeed, it is a
bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of high concernment, the eyes of the whole Kingdome being fixed upon this great Object.

But ≈øome rumour it abroad, that although we have his per≈øon, we cannot attaine his heart; for it is ≈øaid, that his Maie≈øty hath lately ≈øent a Me≈ø≈øage (or Declaration) to the Militia and Citizens of London, declaring his re≈øolution and intention concerning the pre≈øent de≈øign of the Army; the heads wherof, I ≈øhall briefly communicate unto you, as followeth:

The fir≈øt Propo≈øition. 1. His Maje≈øty doth propound, that He hath no de≈øire to comply with the proceedings of the Army ≈øaying, that he admired at their actions, and wondred by what Authority they dur≈øt pre≈øume to do that which they have already done.

2. That He de≈øired to re≈øide no longer at Newmarket, for he found him≈øelf an ab≈øolute pri≈øoner, but with all willingne≈ø≈øe, (according to the Votes of both Hou≈øes of Parliament) would take his Journey towards Richmond, that ≈øo a firme Peace might ≈øpeedily be ≈øetled within the Kingdome of England and Dominion of Wales.

3. That his Maie≈øty de≈øires nothing more earne≈øtly, then to joyn with his two Hou≈øes of Parliament a≈ø≈øembled at We≈øtmin≈øter, that ≈øo by the happy uniting of the Head and Body, there may be a ≈øpeedy compo≈øure of all differences now ari≈øing within this langui≈øhing Kingdome.

4. That for His Maie≈øties having any corre≈øpondencie with the pre≈øent de≈øignes or actions of the Armie, He doth declare to all his loving Subjects the contrary, prote≈øting again≈øt all their proceedings, and that what≈øoever they heard to the contrary, de≈øired them not to believe, no, though under his own hand, unle≈ø≈øe they ≈øpake with one who had it from his own mouth.

Thus have I given you the chiefe heads of his Maie≈øties late Propo≈øitions to the Citizens of London for a ≈øafe and well-grounded peace, I ≈øhall now endeavour to ≈øatisfie your expectation, concerning the late Propo≈øitions ≈øent from the Commi≈ø≈øioners at Newmarket, to his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax at St. Albanes, which followeth in the≈øe words:

1 According to the Votes of both Hou≈øes of Parliament, you are required to deliver the
per≈øon of the King to ≈øuch per≈øons as both Hou≈øes ≈øhall appoint, to be placed at Richmond, under ≈øuch guards, and in ≈øuch manner as they ≈øhall think fit. And ≈øecondly, that your Excellency would be plea≈øed to ≈øend a ≈øpeedy an≈øwer to the Votes of both Hou≈øes, concerning the removall of the per≈øon of his Maie≈øty from Newmarket to Richmond.

After reading of the ≈øaid Propo≈øitions, the Generall ≈øummoned divers Collonels, Lieutenant-Colonels, Majors, and Captains to his quarters, to debate and con≈øult thereupon; but at the clo≈øe of this Letter, they had not concluded of any thing, divers queries being propounded which highly concerned the King: therefore, for further particulars, I refer you to the inclo≈øed papers, and remaine

closer.signed: Your friend and kin≈øman. A. Woorell.
closer.dateline: St. Albanes this 23 of Iune, 7 in the morning.

div.head: The Kings An≈øwer and Re≈øolution upon the delivery of the Votes to his Maje≈øty at Newmarket, being the ≈øub≈øtance of what was ≈øent by Sir Peter Killegrew to the Parliament.
div.p: THat his Maje≈øty is content to remove to Richmond, it being nearer to His Parliament.
That to remove from Newmarket to Richmond, is agreeable to what him≈øelf hath alwayes de≈øired in his late me≈ø≈øages to the Hou≈øes.
That it being neerer to his Parliament, it is much more convenient for treating with the hou≈øes, and concurring in ≈øuch acts as ≈øhall be pa≈ø≈øed for the peace and ≈øecurity of the Kingdome,
That on Thur≈øday next his Maje≈øty may go from Newmarket to Richmond, according to the Votes of both hou≈øes.
His Maje≈øty de≈øires that there may bee ≈øuch a concurrence between his Maje≈øty and the hou≈øes, and ≈øo the Army al≈øo, as may conduce to a ≈øafe and well grounded peace.

Sir, We hear that the Generall hath gave his a≈ø≈øent (together with the Officers and Souldiers of the Army) that his Maje≈øties Royall per≈øon ≈øhall be conducted to Richmond, there to remain, with ≈øuch a Guard, as ≈øhall be thought meet by the Officers and Souldiers under command of his Excellency, to perform ≈øo great a Charge committed to their tru≈øt, with faithfulne≈ø≈øe and fidelity. Wee heare that his Maje≈øty is upon his advance from Newmarket towards Richmond, being conducted with two gallant Regiments of hor≈øe. The Army is much ≈øatisfied with the la≈øt Moneths pay ≈øent down from the Parliament, it having ≈øilenced many, and given great ≈øatisfaction to the re≈øt. By the next you ≈øhall hear further, from

closer.signed: Your mo≈øt offectionate friend and Kin≈øman. A. Woorel.

postscript.p: His Maje≈øties Coach is gone from London towards Newmarket, being a very ≈øumptuous thing, and richly adorned.
